testimony.name: Jeffrey Thomas
key_points: Supports the City of Yes for Housing Opportunity proposal in general
Specifically favors the Universal Affordability Preference (UAP)
UAP makes buildings more profitable while increasing affordable housing
Removing parking minimums can encourage alternative transportation methods
Removing parking minimums can lower construction costs and increase affordability
Fewer parking spaces can lead to less congestion and fewer cars on the roads

talking_point_evidence.quote: I'd like to speak specifically in favor of the universal affordability preference. I think every time we look at new housing as well, why is it more affordable? Why aren't they building more affordable housing? We all support more affordable housing. How do we actually make that happen? How do we make the buildings? Actually get built.
talking_point_evidence.analysis: This quote supports the UAP talking point. While it doesn't use the exact language from the reference points, it emphasizes the need for more affordable housing and questions how to make it happen, which aligns with the goals of UAP.

talking_point_evidence.quote: UAP makes the buildings more profitable because say it's not saying, you know, take some of your existing housing, make make make these units affordable. So you can build even more units that are affordable. It's it's a it's a win win.
talking_point_evidence.analysis: This quote closely aligns with the UAP talking point about making developments more efficient and easier to finance. It also emphasizes the increase in affordable housing, which is a key point in the reference talking points.

talking_point_evidence.quote: I'd also like to speak quickly in favor for moving parking minimums. I know speak people have spoken in favor of that. I'd just like to say personally, because people say, you know, while this won't get people out of their cars, it'll just put more pressure on parking.
talking_point_evidence.analysis: This quote directly supports the talking point about lifting parking minimums. It addresses a common concern and aligns with the reference points about reducing car dependency.

talking_point_evidence.quote: In New York City, especially when especially when you're building new buildings, if you say here's a building with no parking, people who move in will commute with some way other than a private vehicle. That all, as people said, lower cost construction, get us more affordability, hopefully use a space.
talking_point_evidence.analysis: This quote strongly supports the talking points about lifting parking minimums. It mentions lower construction costs and increased affordability, which are key points in the reference talking points. It also touches on the idea of reducing car usage, which aligns with the climate-related points in the reference.
